column1: Alice Springs (Eastern Arrernte: Mparntwe) is the third-largest town in the Northern Territory of Australia. Known as Stuart until 31 August 1933
column2: the name Alice Springs was given by surveyor William Whitfield Mills after Alice
column3: Lady Todd (née Alice Gillam Bell)
column4: wife of the telegraph pioneer Sir Charles Todd.  Now colloquially known as The Alice or simply Alice
column5: the town is situated roughly in Australia's geographic centre. It is nearly equidistant from Adelaide and Darwin.The area is known as Mparntwe to its original inhabitants
column6: the Arrernte
column7: who have lived in the Central Australian desert in and around what is now Alice Springs for tens of thousands of years.

column1: Alice Springs had an urban population of 26
column2: 534 in June 2018
column3: having declined an average of 1.16% per year the preceding five years. The town's population accounts for approximately 10 per cent of the population of the Northern Territory.The town straddles the usually dry Todd River on the northern side of the MacDonnell Ranges. The surrounding region is known as Central Australia
column4: or the Red Centre
column5: an arid environment consisting of several different deserts. Temperatures in Alice Springs can vary
column6: with an average maximum in summer of 35.6 °C (96.1 °F) and an average minimum in winter of 5.1 °C (41.2 °F).

column1: == History ==
=== Traditional inhabitants ===

The Arrernte Aboriginal people have made their home in the Central Australian desert in and around the site of the future Alice Springs for thousands of years; evidence suggests Indigenous occupation of the region dating back at least 30
column2: 000 years. The Aboriginal name for Alice Springs is Mparntwe. Many Arrernte people also live in communities outside of Alice Springs and on outstations.Three major groups — Western
column3: Eastern
column4: and Central Arrernte — live in Central Australia
column5: their traditional land including the area of Alice Springs and MacDonnell Ranges. Their name has been spelt in various forms
column6: including Aranda
column7: Arrarnta
column8: and Arunta. There are five dialects of the Arrernte language: South-eastern
column11: Eastern and North-eastern.Arrernte country is rich with mountain ranges
column13: which create a variety of natural habitats. According to the Arrernte traditional stories
column14: in the desert surrounding Alice Springs
column15: the landscape was shaped by caterpillars

column1: The numerous sites of traditional importance in and around Alice Springs include Anthwerrke (Emily Gap)
column2: Akeyulerre (Billy Goat Hill)
column3: Ntaripe (Heavitree Gap)
column4: Atnelkentyarliweke (Anzac Hill) and Alhekulyele (Mt Gillen).

column1: === European colonisation ===

column2: John McDouall Stuart led an expedition through Central Australia
column3: to the west of what later became Alice Springs
column4: thereby establishing a route from the south of the continent to the north.A white settlement named after Stuart was started ten years later with the construction of a repeater station on the Australian Overland Telegraph Line (OTL)
column5: which linked Adelaide to Darwin and Great Britain. The OTL was completed in 1872. It traced Stuart's route and opened up the interior for permanent settlement. The Alice Springs Telegraph Station was sited near what was thought to be a permanent waterhole in the normally dry Todd River
column6: named Alice Springs by W.W. Mills after the wife of the Superintendent of Telegraphs and Postmaster General of South Australia
column7: Sir Charles Todd
column8: who was the driving force for constructing the OTL. The nearby settlement of Stuart was renamed as Alice Springs on 31 August 1933. The Todd River and its tributary the Charles River
column9: which meet near the telegraph station

column1: It was not until alluvial gold was discovered at Arltunga
column2: 100 kilometres (62 mi) east of the present Alice Springs
column3: in 1887 that any significant European settlement occurred. The town's first substantial building was the Stuart Town Gaol in Parson's Street; this was built in 1909
column4: when the town had a European population of fewer than 20 people. Many of the gaol's first prisoners were first-contact aboriginal men incarcerated for killing cattle. The first aircraft
column5: piloted by Francis Stewart Briggs landed in 1921. Central Australia's first hospital
column6: Adelaide House
column7: was built in 1926 when the European population of the town was about 40. It was not until 1929
column8: when the train line to Alice was built
column9: that the town's European population began to grow. Aboriginal Centralians outnumbered European Centralians until the mid-1930s. From 1926 to 1931
column10: Alice Springs was the seat of government for the now-defunct Territory of Central Australia. Until 31 August 1933
column11: the town was officially known as Stuart.

column1: The original mode of British-Australian transportation in the outback were camel trains
column2: operated by immigrants from Pathan tribes in the North-West Frontier of then-British India (present-day Pakistan); known locally as Afghan cameleers based at Hergott Springs
column3: or Marree as it is now known. Many cameleers moved to Alice Springs in 1929 when the railway finally reached the town. They lived on the block where the town council is now
column4: transporting goods from the rail head to stations and settlements to the north. A gold rush in Tennant Creek in 1932 kept the wheels of the Alice Springs economy turning until the outbreak of World War II.Alice Springs was connected to Darwin by rail on 4 February 2004
column5: when the first passenger train arrived in Darwin from Adelaide.

column1: === World War II ===
World War II brought significant changes to Alice Springs. Prior to the war
column2: Alice Springs was an extremely isolated settlement of fewer than 500 people. During the war
column3: however
column4: the town was an extremely active staging base
column5: known as No. 9 Australian Staging Camp
column6: and a depot base for the long four-day trip to Darwin. The railway hub in Alice Springs was taken over by military operations and the number of soldiers posted in Alice Springs grew rapidly
column7: as did the number of personnel passing through on their way to and from Darwin. When Darwin was threatened by Japanese forces
column8: the sea routes—the Northern Territory capital's primary means of transportation and resupply—were cut off. The evacuation of Darwin first brought a large number of civilians including elected officials and many of the territory government's records. Alice Springs became the war-time civilian capital of the Northern Territory. When Darwin was bombed by Japanese air forces
column9: a large number of military personnel and their heavy equipment were rapidly moved south to Alice Springs.

column1: The number of soldiers posted in Alice Springs peaked at around 8
column2: 000 and the number of personnel passing through totalled close to 200
column3: 000. Once the war ended
column4: the military camps and the evacuees departed
column5: and Alice Springs' population declined rapidly. After being visited by nearly 200
column6: 000 people
column7: including the American General Douglas MacArthur
column8: Alice Springs gained considerable fame. The war years also left behind many structures. The historically-listed Totem Theatre
column9: created for the entertainment of this camp
column10: still exists today. The Australian Army set up the 109th Australian General Hospital at Alice Springs. Seven Mile Aerodrome was constructed by the Royal Australian Air Force. War-related operations necessitated the first sealing of the road between Alice Springs and Larrimah
column11: expansion and improvement of Alice Springs' water supply
column12: and improving the rail head. The war-related operations left behind thousands of pieces of excess military equipment and vehicles
column13: and a marked increase in Alice Springs' population.During World War II
column14: Alice Springs was the location of RAAF No. 24 Inland Aircraft Fuel Depot (IAFD)
column15: completed on 20 May 1942 and closed in November 1944. Each usually consisting of four tanks
column16: 31 fuel depots were built across Australia for the storage and supply of aircraft fuel for the RAAF and the US Army Air Forces

column1: === After World War II ===
During the 1960s Alice Springs became an important defence location with the development of the US/Australian Pine Gap joint defence satellite monitoring base
column2: home to about 700 workers from both countries.

column1: By far the major industry in recent times is tourism. Almost in the exact centre of the continent
column2: Alice Springs is some 1
column3: 200 kilometres (750 mi) from the nearest ocean and 1
column4: 500 kilometres (930 mi) from the nearest major cities
column5: Darwin and Adelaide. Alice Springs is at the midpoint of the Adelaide–Darwin Railway.

column1: === Modern town ===
The modern town of Alice Springs has both European and Aboriginal influences. The town's focal point
column2: the Todd Mall
column3: hosts a number of Aboriginal art galleries and community events. Alice Springs' desert lifestyle has inspired several unique events
column4: such as the Camel Cup
column5: the Henley-on-Todd Regatta
column6: Beanie Festival and the Tatts Finke Desert Race.

column1: === Built environment ===
Alice Springs has many historic buildings
column2: including the Overland Telegraph Station
column3: the Old Courthouse and Residency and the Hartley Street School. Adelaide House
column4: a beautiful stone building in the middle of the Mall
column5: Central Australia's first hospital
column6: was designed and built by the Rev. John Flynn
column7: founder of the world's first flying doctor service
column8: in 1926. It was also the site of the world's first successful portable wireless radio experiment conducted by Alf Traeger. Today it is a museum
column9: one of several significant tourist attractions which form part of 'The Flynn Trail' a self-guided urban heritage trail.Today
column10: the town is an important tourist hub and service centre for the surrounding area. It is a well-appointed town for its size
column13: and a good range of visitor attractions

column1: == Geography ==

The region around Alice Springs is part of the Central Ranges xeric scrub area of dry scrubby grassland and includes the MacDonnell Ranges which run east and west of the town and contain a number of hiking trails and swimming holes such as Ormiston Gorge
column2: Ormiston Gorge Creek
column3: Red Bank Gorge and Glen Helen Gorge. The 223-kilometre-long (139 mi) Larapinta Trail follows the West MacDonnell Ranges and is considered among the world's great walking experiences.

column1: The Simpson Desert
column2: southeast of Alice Springs is one of Australia's great wilderness areas containing giant
column3: red sand dunes and interesting rock formations such as Chambers Pillar and Rainbow Valley.

column1: === Climate ===
Under the Köppen climate classification
column2: Alice Springs has a subtropical hot desert climate (BWh)
column3: featuring extremely hot
column4: dry summers and short
column5: mild winters. Located just south of the Tropic of Capricorn
column6: the town of Alice Springs straddles the usually dry Todd River on the northern side of the MacDonnell Ranges. Alice Springs is located in Central Australia
column7: also called the Red Centre
column8: an arid environment consisting of several different deserts.  The annual average rainfall is 285.9 millimetres (11.3 in) which would make it a semi-arid climate except that its high evapotranspiration
column10: makes it a desert climate.Annual precipitation is erratic
column11: varying year to year in Alice Springs. In 2001 741 millimetres (29.2 in) fell and in 2002 only 198 millimetres (7.8 in) fell. The highest daily rainfall is 204.8 millimetres (8.06 in)

column1: Temperatures in Alice Springs vary widely
column2: and rainfall can vary quite dramatically from year to year. In summer
column3: the average maximum temperature is in the mid-30s
column4: whereas in winter the average minimum temperature can be 5.5 °C (41.9 °F)
column5: with an average of 12.4 nights below freezing every year
column6: providing frost. The elevation of the town is about 545 metres (1
column7: 788 feet)
column8: which contributes to the cool nights in winter. The highest temperature on record is 47.5 °C (117.5 °F) first recorded on 24 December 1891
column10: recorded on 17 July 1976. This is also the lowest temperature recorded in the Northern Territory.

column1: == Demographics ==
According to the 2016 census of population
column2: there were 23
column3: 726 people in the Alice Springs Urban Area.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 18.1% of the population.
64.2% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were New Zealand 3.6%
column2: United States of America 2.8%
column3: India 2.8%
column4: England 2.6% and Philippines 2.1%.

column1: 68.3% of people only spoke English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Malayalam 1.7%
column2: Arrernte 1.0%
column3: Tagalog 1.0%
column4: Mandarin Chinese 0.8% and Filipino 0.8%.

column1: The most common responses for religion were No Religion 32.5% and Catholic 18.8%.
=== Aboriginal population ===
As Alice Springs is the regional hub of Central Australia
column2: it attracts Aboriginal people from all over that region and well beyond. Many Aboriginal people visit regularly to use the town's services. Aboriginal residents usually live in the suburbs
column3: on special purpose leases (or town camps)
column4: or further out at Amoonguna to the south and on the small family outstation communities on Aboriginal lands in surrounding areas.The traditional owners of the Alice Springs area are the Central Arrernte people. As it is the largest town in central Australia
column5: there are also speakers of Warlpiri
column6: Warumungu
column7: Kaytetye

column1: === Foreign and itinerant populations ===
==== American population ====
Americans have lived in Alice Springs continuously since the establishment of the United States Air Force Detachment 421
column2: in 1954. Currently located on Schwarz Crescent
column3: it is part of a joint American–Australian project called the Joint Geological and Geographical Research Station (JGGRS). The unit is locally known as "Det 421" or "The Det" and has sponsored as many as 25 American families to live as temporary residents of the Alice Springs district.

column1: To mark the longstanding friendship with the community
column2: on 1 July 1995
column3: the Alice Springs Town Council granted Detachment 421 freedom of entry to the Alice Springs. Since the early 1970s
column4: the majority of the American population in Alice Springs has been associated with proximity to Pine Gap
column5: a joint Australian-US satellite tracking station
column6: located 19 kilometres (12 mi) south-west of Alice Springs
column7: that employs about 700 Americans and Australians.

column1: Currently
column3: 000 residents of the Alice Springs district hold American citizenship. Many of these
column4: joined by some Australians
column5: celebrate major American public holidays
column6: including the 4th of July and Thanksgiving. Americans in Alice Springs are also known to participate in a variety of associations and sporting teams
column7: including baseball

column1: ==== Other cultures ====
Several small immigrant communities of other foreign cultures have found a home in Alice Springs
column2: including Vietnamese
column3: Chinese
column4: Thai
column5: Sudanese and Indian ethnic groups. The most obvious impact of their presence in such a small and isolated town has been the opening of various restaurants serving their traditional cuisines.

column1: ==== Itinerant population ====
Alice Springs has a large itinerant population. This population is generally composed of foreign and Australian tourists
column2: Aboriginal Australians visiting from nearby Central Australian communities
column3: and Australian or international workers on short-term contracts (colloquially referred to as "blow-ins"). The major sources of work that recruit workers into town are the stations
column4: mines
column5: healthcare and law enforcement. Foreign tourists usually pass through on their way to Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park
column6: whilst Australian tourists usually come through as a part of an event such as the Masters Games and the Finke Desert Race. These events can cause the population of the town to fluctuate by several thousand within a matter of days.

column1: == Government ==
The Alice Springs Town Council governs the Alice Springs area
column2: which takes in the town centre
column3: its suburbs and some rural area. The Alice Springs Town Council has governed Alice Springs since 1971. The Alice Springs council consists of nine members: the mayor and eight aldermen. The town is not divided up into wards. The current mayor of Alice Springs is Damien Ryan. Council Meetings are held on the last Monday of each month. The Alice Springs Region is governed by the newly created MacDonnell Region local government area
column4: for which Alice Springs serves as council seat.

column1: Alice Springs and the surrounding region have four elected members to the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. Araluen and Braitling are entirely within Alice Springs
column2: while the mostly rural seats of Gwoja (known as Stuart before 2020) and Namatjira spill into the town. Historically
column3: Alice Springs has tilted conservative. It was a stronghold for the Country Liberal Party for many years; only the northeast (part of which is in Stuart) leans Labor. However
column4: these trends were dramatically altered at the 2016 election. Former Chief Minister and Alice Springs resident Adam Giles lost Braitling to Labor
column5: Araluen was retained by CLP-turned-independent Robyn Lambley
column6: and Namatjira and Stuart fell to Labor. As a result
column7: the CLP was completely shut out of Alice Springs for the first time ever. The CLP regained Braitling and Namatjira in 2020
column8: while Lambley retained Araluen for her new party

column1: In the Australian House of Representatives
column2: Alice Springs is part of the Division of Lingiari
column3: which includes all of the Territory outside the Darwin/Palmerston area. Lingiari is currently held by Labor member and Alice Springs resident Warren Snowdon.

column1: == Economy ==
Alice Springs began as a service town to the pastoral industry that first came to the region. The introduction of the rail line increased its economy. Today the town services a region of 546
column2: 046 square kilometres (210
column3: 830 sq mi) and a regional population of 38
column4: 749. The region includes a number of mining and pastoral communities
column5: the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap and tourist attractions at Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park
column6: Watarrka National Park and the MacDonnell Ranges.

column1: The largest employer in Alice Springs is the Northern Territory Government
column2: with 8% of employed people working in government administration
column3: 7% in school education
column4: and 4% in the Alice Springs Hospital. The economy of Alice Springs is somewhat reliant on domestic and international tourism
column5: with 4% of its workforce employed providing accommodation.

column1: As well as Territory Discoveries
column2: all major tour companies have a base in Alice Springs
column3: including AAT Kings & APT
column4: as well as numerous local operators
column5: including Emu Run Tours
column6: Anganu Waai! tours
column7: Alice Wanderer and Wayoutback Desert Safaris
column8: the only locally based Advanced Ecotourism Accredited operator.

column1: Alice Springs is home to numerous hotels
column2: from the ​4 1⁄2-star Lasseters Hotel Casino
column3: to backpacker hostels. There are also caravan parks.

column1: A dispatch centre for the Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia operates here.
== Education ==
Education is overseen territory-wide by the Department of Education and Training (DET). It works to continually improve education outcomes for all students
column2: with a focus on Indigenous students.

column1: === Preschool
column2: primary and secondary ===

column1: Alice Springs is served by nineteen public and private schools that cater to local and overseas students. Over 3
column2: 843 primary and secondary students are enrolled in schools in Alice Springs
column3: with 2
column4: 187 students attending primary education
column5: and 1
column6: 656 students attending secondary education. There are over 1
column7: 932 students enrolled in government schools and 1
column8: 055 students enrolled in independent schools.Alice Springs has an Alice Springs School of the Air which delivers education to students in remote areas.

column1: === Tertiary and vocational ===

The Alice Springs Campus of Charles Darwin University offers courses in TAFE and higher education. The Centre for Appropriate Technology was established in 1980 and provides a range of services to encourage and help Aboriginal people enhance their quality of life in remote communities.
== Recreation and culture ==
=== Events and festivals ===
The town's focal point
column2: the Todd Mall
column3: hosts a number of Aboriginal art galleries and community events. Alice Springs' desert lifestyle has inspired several unique events
column4: such as the Alice Desert Festival
column5: the Red Centre NATS
column6: Parrtjima
column7: the Camel Cup
column9: the Beanie Festival and the Finke Desert Race. The Finke Desert Race is a 'there and back' challenge from Alice Springs to Aputula (Finke) Community

column1: === Arts and entertainment ===
==== Galleries and museums ====
Alice Springs is known as the Aboriginal Art capital of Central Australia
column2: home to many local and Aboriginal art galleries. Indigenous Australian art is the more dominant
column3: and galleries showcase the rich culture and native traditions that abound in Central Australia. Trade in Aboriginal art soared after the painting movement began at Papunya
column4: a Central Australian Aboriginal settlement
column5: and swept other indigenous communities. Central Australia is the home of some of the most prominent names in Aboriginal art
column6: including Emily Kngwarreye
column7: Minnie Pwerle

column1: The Museum of Central Australia / Stehlow Research Centre feature some of the most important natural history and archival materials tied to the history and culture of the region. The Strehlow Archives also contain materials linked to the Arrernte people of Central Australia. The Araluen Centre for Arts and Entertainment presents world-class ballets and orchestras
column2: as well as local performances. The Women's Museum of Australia (formerly National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame) is located in the grounds of Old Alice Springs Gaol in the Heritage Precinct. Here women's stories from across Australia are presented with the lives of outback women as well as stories from the Old Gaol and Labour Prison. Objects include a large "Signature" quilt with signatures of over 300 women first in their field and a 4.2 m long Aviatrix tapestry celebrating the high flying lives of Australia's women aviatrixes.

column1: The town has some excellent small museums. The extensive collection at the Old Timer's Traeger Museum on the North Stuart Highway includes artefacts from the town's early Afghan and German residents
column2: traditional Aboriginal artefacts and objects which show the early fusion of European and Aboriginal cultures
column3: such as a spinifex-handled glass-bladed knife. Included in the collection are soapstone carvings by Arrernte artist Erlikilyika.

column1: === Outdoors ===
Leisure and entertainment activities include hiking in the nearby MacDonnell Ranges
column2: driving the four-wheel-drive tracks at Finke Gorge National Park.

column1: ==== Parks and gardens ====
The Alice Springs Desert Park was created to educate visitors about the many facets of the surrounding desert environment. The arid climate botanic garden
column2: Olive Pink Botanic Garden
column3: is a short distance from the town centre. They were named after anthropologist
column4: naturalist and artist Olive Pink
column5: who lived in the town for almost 30 years and died in 1975. She was well known locally and referred to by all as Miss Pink. The Alice Springs Reptile Centre is located in the town centre.

column1: Alice Springs has a high rate of participation in many different sports
column2: including tennis
column3: hockey
column4: Australian rules football
column5: basketball
column6: baseball
column7: golf

column1: soccer
column2: cricket
column3: rugby and boxing.

column1: Australian rules football is a particularly popular sport in Alice Springs in terms of both participation and as a spectator sport. The Central Australian Football League formed in 1947 has several teams. The sport is particularly popular in Indigenous communities. The local stadium
column2: Traeger Park
column3: has a 10
column4: 000 seat capacity and was designed to host (pre-season) AFL and is currently home to the Northern Territory Thunder. In 2004
column5: an AFL pre-season Regional Challenge match between Collingwood Football Club and Port Adelaide Football Club attracted a capacity sell-out crowd.

column1: Rugby league has been a part of the local sporting scene since 1963. The Australian Rugby League has held a number of pre-season games in Alice Springs
column2: at ANZAC Oval. The local competition is the Central Australian Rugby Football League
column3: and sanctions both Junior and Senior Rugby League matches. The season usually kicks off around March/April and runs through to Late August. There are 4 senior teams in Alice Springs; Wests
column4: Memo
column5: United and Vikings. Matches are held during the winter months at ANZAC oval on Saturday afternoons.

column1: Organized baseball has been played in Alice Springs since the mid-1950s. Currently under the national organisation of the Australian Baseball Federation
column2: the Alice Springs Baseball Association organises baseball competitions for youth players aged 5 to 18 and an adult competition played at Jim McConville Park and on Lyel Kempster Field at Traeger Park. As part of the worldwide Little League network
column3: Alice Springs players and compete in the Australian National Little League competitions.

column1: A must visit for all golfers is the Alice Springs Golf Course. A challenging 18 hole championship layout designed by renowned golf course Architects
column2: Thomson Wolveridge. Opened in 1985 by a challenge match between top professionals Greg Norman and Johnny Miller. With wonderful green fairways carved between the red rocky hills and dust of Central Australia
column3: the course has been a regular feature of Australias top 100 courses since its early days. The course record of 64 is held jointly by
column4: amateur members
column5: Leigh Shacklady and Kerryn Heaver
column6: beating professional Stuart Appleby's 65. Adam Scott won the Australian Boys Amateur Championship held there in 1997.

column1: Cricket is a popular sport in Alice Springs and is primarily played at Traeger Park. The Imparja Cup Cricket Carnival first was played in 1994 and attracts Indigenous teams from all across Australia. The four main clubs are Federal Demons CC
column2: Rovers CC
column3: RSL Works CC and Wests CC.

column1: Soccer is very popular among the younger community. A high number of children play it. Soccer is also played frequently by amateur adults in different divisions. There is also an all-African league for soccer in Alice Springs. The most successful Club in the town is Alice Springs Celtic.
The Traeger Park sporting complex also hosts tennis
column2: baseball
column3: boxing
column4: swimming
column5: canoe polo
column6: hockey
column7: basketball

column1: A unique sporting event
column2: held annually
column3: is the Henley-on-Todd Regatta
column4: also known as the Todd River Race. It is a sand river race with bottomless boats and it remains the only dry river regatta in the world. Another unusual sporting event is the Camel Cup. The annual Camel Cup is held in July at Blatherskite Park
column5: part of the Central Australian Show Society grounds. It is a full day event featuring a series of races using camels instead of horses.

column1: Every year
column2: on the Queen's Birthday long weekend
column3: the annual Finke Desert Race is held. It is a gruelling off-road race that runs from Alice Springs to the Finke community
column4: then back again the next day. The total length of the race is roughly 500 kilometres (310 mi). It attracts spectators
column5: who camp along the whole length of the track
column6: and roughly 500 competitors
column7: buggies and bikes
column9: making it the biggest sporting event in the Alice Springs calendar.

column1: Drag racing is held at the Alice Springs Inland Dragway which in June 2013 hosted a round of the national Aeroflow Sportsman Drag Racing Championship. In September 2017 12 people were injured when burning fuel sprayed from a drag-racing car onto a crowd of spectators at the Red CentreNATS competition.Alice Springs is also home to the Arunga Park Speedway
column2: a 402-metre dirt oval speedway. The speedway runs from August to March and caters to cars
column3: solos and sidecars. Located just off the Stuart Highway on the northern edge of the town
column4: Arunga Park hosted the Australian Sidecar Championship in 1985 and the Australian Solo Championship in 1991.

column1: == Crime ==
Property crime and violent crime
column2: including domestic violence
column3: often linked to alcohol abuse
column4: has been a significant social issue in Alice Springs in the 21st century
column5: with most of the victims being residents of the town. Many approaches and programs have been tried over the years
column6: with varying levels of success. As of 2019 there has been a downward trend in most categories of crime.

column1: == In popular culture ==
The TV series Pine Gap (2018) is set around the Australian and American joint defence intelligence facility at Pine Gap
column2: located near Alice Springs.

column1: Liz Phair included a song called "Alice Springs" on her 1994 album Whip Smart.
The group Midnight Oil mention Alice Springs in their songs "Kosciusko" and "Warakurna" ('There is enough in Redfern as there is in Alice'); and they mention Pine Gap in "Power and the Passion".
The well-known Australian song "My Island Home" was originally written about the experience of an islander living 'west of Alice Springs'
column2: and this is mentioned in the lyrics of the original Warumpi Band version of the song.

column1: Nevil Shute's novel A Town Like Alice
column2: and the resulting film and television mini-series
column3: take their name from Alice Springs
column4: although little of the action takes place there; because part of the story is set in Willstown (possibly modelled on Burketown) situated north of Alice Springs
column5: near the Gulf of Carpentaria. The heroine
column6: Jean
column7: wants to change Willstown into a town "like" Alice. The local library in Alice Springs is named after Nevil Shute: the Nevil Shute Memorial Library.

column1: Lasseters Casino in Alice Springs is the destination for the drag queen protagonists in the Australian road movie The Adventures of Priscilla
column2: Queen of the Desert. The movie became a hit West End show
column3: before transferring to Broadway.

column1: Alice Springs is featured in Bruce Chatwin's 1987 travelogue The Songlines
column2: recounting the author's retreat into the Australian Outback in search of the Aboriginals' Dreaming-tracks.

column1: Alice Springs is featured in Bill Bryson's 2000 travelogue Down Under (also known as "In a Sunburned Country"). Bryson visits and describes the scenes of Alice Springs including the Telegraph Office
column2: the Springs
column3: and his trip to Uluru from Alice Springs.

column1: Dick Diver released a song called "Alice" on the 2013 album Calendar Days.
The opening track of Mystery Jets' 2011 album Serotonin is entitled "Alice Springs"
column2: inspired by a tour in Australia.

column1: Ian Moss released a song called "Such a Beautiful Thing" on the 1988 album Matchbook
column2: which contains the lyrics 'thinking back to Alice Springs'.  He has stated that he wrote the song as a tribute to the Northern Territory.

column1: == Media ==

Alice Springs is served by both local and national radio and television services. The government-owned ABC provides four broadcast radio stations – local radio 783 ABC Alice Springs and the national networks ABC Radio National
column2: ABC Classic FM and Triple J. The national Christian radio network Vision Radio Network broadcasts on 88.0 FM.

column1: Commercial radio stations are 8HA 900 kHz and Sun 96.9 MHz and community radio is provided by 8CCC 102.1FM and indigenous broadcaster CAAMA Radio 100.5 MHz.
Alice Springs is home to Australia's largest Indigenous media company. The Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) consists of a radio station (CAAMA Radio)
column2: Music recording label (CAAMA Music)
column3: television and film production company (CAAMA Productions) and CAAMA technical. CAAMA serves to record and promote indigenous talent across its own radio network (one of the largest transmission footprints in the world)
column4: and through sales of CD's and screening of CAAMA movies and documentaries on national broadcasters.

column1: Five broadcast television services operate in Alice Springs – commercial stations Imparja Television (callsign IMP-9)
column2: Southern Cross Central (QQQ31) and Ten Central (CDT) (CDT-5)
column3: and the Government-owned ABC (ABAD7) and SBS (SBS28). Imparja has a commercial agreement with the Nine network. Southern Cross Central and Ten Central have programming affiliations with both the Seven Network and Network Ten Australia.

column1: Digital television transmissions have commenced in Alice Springs. New channels provided by the ABC and SBS can be received with a digital set top box or digital television. Additional channels from the commercial broadcasters that are available in most other areas of Australia are expected to commence transmission in 2011–2012. Analogue television transmissions in Alice Springs switched off on 31 December 2013.

Imparja Television is operated from studios in Alice Springs. It has a program affiliation contract with the Nine Network. The programming schedule on Imparja is the same as Nine Darwin NTD-8 and Channel 9 Brisbane
column2: with variations in Imparja's schedule for local Australian rules football
column3: rugby league
column4: the children's show Yamba's Playtime
column5: news
column6: regional weather
column7: and other programs produced in Alice Springs by the station. Infomercials are shown in place of Home Shopping and other programs overnight and in some daytime timeslots. NITV is broadcast on the second channel allocated to Imparja by the Federal Government.

column1: The Centralian Advocate newspaper was founded on 24 May 1947 and was published on Tuesdays and Fridays. However
column2: since 2013
column3: printing of the Centralian Advocate has stopped.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Transport ===
Located on the Adelaide-Darwin railway
column2: Alice Springs is accessible by train. Alice Springs railway station is visited by The Ghan
column3: operated by Great Southern Rail
column4: on its journey between Adelaide and Darwin. The train arrives twice weekly in each direction.The line first opened to Alice Springs in 1929
column5: as the narrow gauge Central Australia Railway. It was not until 1980 that the current standard gauge line was opened
column6: which was extended to Darwin in 2004.

column1: There are daily express coach services to and from Adelaide and Darwin servicing Alice Springs. The Stuart Highway
column2: running north from Adelaide to Darwin via Alice Springs
column3: is Northern Territory's most important road. The distance from Alice Springs to Adelaide is 1
column4: 530 kilometres (950 mi) and to Darwin is 1
column5: 498 kilometres (931 mi).

column1: There are daily flights from Alice Springs Airport to Adelaide
column2: Ayers Rock (Uluru)
column3: Cairns
column4: Darwin
column5: Melbourne
column6: Perth and Sydney. There are also nonstop flights a few times a week to Brisbane. Two airlines serve Alice Springs: Qantas and Virgin Australia.Alice Springs is a base for the Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia.
